message: Happy New Year to all of my constituents! I hope 2017 brings great things for you and your families.

It’s a new year and a new low for House Republicans, opening the 115th Congress by stripping critical oversight and accountability procedures from the Office of Congressional Ethics. I cannot understand how anyone could justify voting for this measure. The Office of Congressional Ethics is currently an independent, non-partisan entity. The office has, historically, been able to investigate wrongdoing by Members of Congress, including anonymous reports by whistleblowers. By stripping this office of its power and instead transferring oversight to the House Ethics Committee – into the very hands of those who could be subject to such investigations – House Republicans have betrayed the trust of their constituents.  This is a disheartening start to the new Congress, to say the very least, and I condemn this move in the strongest terms possible. This is a time of uncertainty for so many in this country, and reducing accountability and transparency, effectively giving Members of Congress a free pass, does nothing to alleviate the very real concerns of those questioning who and what their elected leaders truly represent.

As the new Congress begins, I'm also looking back at 2016. Follow along this week as I post some of last year's highlights from my office.   Communicating with my constituentsand being accessible is a priority, and social media is a huge part of that! #Langevin2016
My favorite place to be is in Rhode Island, meeting people and talking about their concerns. That feedback shapes my policy work in Washington. #Langevin2016
One of the ways I solicit feedback is through my eight advisory committees, made up of hundreds of community leaders. #Langevin2016

In the 114th Congress, I worked on many pieces of important policy and saw five of my proposals signed into law, including my CARDER Act to crack down on identity theft, my Transit Accessibility measure to improve accessible public transportation, and my initiative to better connect classrooms to careers by empowering school counselors to understand and educate young people on workforce trends. #Langevin2016

Last year, more than $750 million in federal funding came into Rhode Island to support education, infrastructure, job training, environmental protection, and more. My office also directly helped constituents realize savings and receive federal benefits they were owed to the tune of $660,105. #Langevin2016

No matter what political climate I face in D.C. or what obstacles are out of our control, I can always ensure that my office is providing quality constituent services. Last year, we corresponded with constituents more than 14,000 times, and my team closed 713 cases for constituents in need of our help on everything from Social Security to veterans benefits to housing issues. #Langevin2016

Thank you for following along this week, and thank you for allowing me to continue to represent Rhode Island in 2017. I promise to work hard this year to represent your interests, bring critical federal funding into Rhode Island, and provide high-quality constituent services to all! #Langevin2016

Thank you so much to Secretary of the Navy Ray Mabus for honoring me with the Distinguished Public Service Award, the United States Navy’s highest honor bestowed upon a civilian not employed by the Department. I am humbled by this incredible honor, and grateful to have had the opportunity to support, in some small way, the important work of Secretary Mabus and all the brave men and women who serve our country in the United States Navy and across all branches of the military. I continuously strive to be a strong and supportive partner to our veterans and to those who serve with distinction, and I will continue to be a fierce advocate for policies that empower and protect these dedicated service members.

January is National Mentoring Month, and I can’t help but think of the men and women who have inspired me over the years, and taught me about true public service. This year, in particular, I remember fondly the late Melvoid Benson, who passed away in June, and who fought tirelessly on behalf of her constituents. I’m also grateful for the people and agencies who work hard to empower mentors and forge these important connections, like the Rhode Island Mentoring Partnership. This month, consider giving some of your time to a child in need – the benefits are immeasurable for mentor and child alike. #MentorIRL

The new session of Congress is now underway, so I wanted to highlight an important part of my website. If you’re interested in learning more about my positions and what Congress is working on, you can track every vote I take on the “Voting Record” page of my website.

Repealing the Affordable Care Act could have enormous consequences, especially for the people in this country who can least afford health coverage. Seniors could lose essential Medicare benefits, people with disabilities and low-income children could lose access to critical coverage, middle-class families could see premiums begin to skyrocket, Rhode Island could lose thousands of jobs, and insurance companies would resume control of Americans’ health care.  To dismantle the Affordable Care Act is to ignore the needs of our constituents. And to my constituents in Rhode Island who have shared their stories of how health care reform has changed their lives, I say this: we will continue to fight. We will fight for the economic security of American families, and we will fight for the health and well-being of the American people.

These are strange, uncertain times, and I’ve heard from many constituents who are afraid of what lies ahead. I share your fears. Hate, violence, discrimination – there is too much of it in our country, and it is being normalized and even endorsed by those even in the highest positions of leadership.   But as First Lady Michelle Obama has said, “When they go low, we go high.” Her words reminded me of Dr. King. Now, more than ever, we must band together in unity against those who seek to divide us. We must show courage of conviction for those who are too afraid to speak out. And above all else, we must show kindness to our friends and our enemies alike. Because as Dr. King taught us, “hate cannot drive out hate. Only love can do that.” #MLKDay

The decision of whether or not to attend the inauguration has been a difficult one. I respect the office of the President, and yet, I am disheartened and angered by Donald Trump's complete and continued failure to rise to the level of dignity, honor, and leadership that this office demands. He directed his most recent tirade at a civil rights hero, legend, statesman, and true public servant, my colleague, Congressman John Lewis. It has been an honor to work alongside Congressman Lewis, and I both understand and support his reasons for boycotting the inauguration. Quite the contrary to the President-elect’s recent statements, Congressman Lewis is a man of both action and principle.  While I take great umbrage at the policies and positions of the President-elect, I have the greatest respect for the office. I hope that Mr. Trump will feel the awesome responsibility of the mantle placed upon him on Friday and will cease his irresponsible, dangerous, and insulting behavior. When I attend the inauguration, I will do so to remind him that the communities that he so frequently and flippantly attacks are watching. I will attend as someone with a disability who refuses to normalize the President-elect’s behavior. I will attend as someone representing so many constituents who are afraid of what this presidency will bring. I will attend to show the President-elect that we aren’t going anywhere, and we will not be silent.

I want to say thank you again to everyone who came out to the Save Health Care Day of Action at the Johnston Senior Center on Sunday. I was amazed by the turnout and by the passion of everyone there. To reach capacity in that building and have an overflow crowd outside – on a cold Sunday during a long weekend, no less – is really a testament to how important health care is to our community, and I will keep fighting so that we don’t lose all the progress we’ve made. #OurFirstStand

I was proud to speak on the House floor last week in support of National Mentoring Month. Mentors inspire confidence, and there are demonstrable benefits – educational, social and emotional – for young people who spend time with a mentor. Later today, I’ll be at Amgen to support the launch of the Million Women Mentors program in Rhode Island, another initiative that will help young people, and young women, in particular, to pursue their dreams and be successful. #MentorIRL

Tomorrow is a new day, and tomorrow, we get back to work to protect the promise of this nation: that every person is treated equally, regardless of race, religion, sexual orientation or identity, or disability. I’m looking forward to being at the Women's March on Washington - Rhode Island tomorrow at the State House to show my support for the #WomensMarch and for the many Rhode Islanders who are afraid of what the future holds. I hope to see many of you tomorrow, but for all of you, regardless of how you feel about this administration, please stay engaged and vocal about the issues that matter most to you!

In his first day on the job, President Trump issued an Executive Order (EO) that solidifies a reckless plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act without a clear path forward. His EO fails to ensure the continuity of health coverage for the millions of Americans who depend on the benefits and services provided by the ACA. Under the guise of regulatory flexibility, the EO may reduce the enforcement of key ACA provisions, a move that could cause widespread uncertainty in the individual insurance market and harm the American people. I’m disappointed Trump has put the health of families on the line. As I have often said, the ACA is not a perfect law, but it represented a huge step forward in health care reform, and we cannot afford to start from scratch. I call on the President and Republicans in Congress to instead come to the table to improve the ACA and protect access to affordable, accessible and high quality health care for all.

What an amazing crowd and an amazing day. The Women's March on Washington - Rhode Island was truly democracy in action. I was there on behalf of women, people of color, the LGBTQ community, people of all faiths, and people with disabilities. I was there on behalf of marginalized communities. If the passion on display today is any indication, we are stronger and more mobilized than ever. #WomensMarch #WhyIMarch

Today would have been the 78th birthday of Ed Roberts, a champion of disability rights who fought for inclusion and accessibility for all. I’m glad to see Google pay homage to the late Roberts today, because now, maybe more than ever, I’m feeling grateful for and indebted to the men and women who have fought and continue to fight for dignity, compassion, and equal rights for all people.

I’m proud to support the Democracy for All Amendment that would reverse Citizens United and McCuthcheon v. FEC. No one should be able to buy unlimited influence in our democracy, and this effort would restore integrity to our electoral process. #GetMoneyOut

I’ve got new blogs up, including a post on the #OurFirstStand Save Health Care Day of Action, which attracted an incredible crowd to the Johnston Senior Center. It’s amazing to see so many Rhode Islanders engaged and activated to fight for the issues that are important to them, and I’m so grateful to everyone who attended the rally. Other new blogs feature the Rhode Island Food System Summit at the University of Rhode Island, and a moving celebration and remembrance of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. at the Ebenezer Baptist Church.   #RITalksFood #MLKDay

Do we need immigration reform? Absolutely. Stronger border security is part of the solution, but President Trump’s claims about a porous southern border oversimplify the challenges we face in our immigration policy. We should instead be looking at the bipartisan comprehensive immigration reform bill that passed the Senate in 2013, which contained provisions to strengthen border security, reform our visa programs, and provide a legal path to citizenship. Building a wall on the taxpayer’s dime would be ineffective and inefficient. You’re talking about a 19th century solution to a 21st century problem, and I remain committed to working on a reform solution that addresses immigration policy as a whole.

To my constituents in South County, your concerns have been heard and I'm with you: the current NEC Future Tier 1 rail plan’s siting for rail rebuilding in Washington County is not viable. I am a strong proponent of high-speed rail projects and believe that service must be updated in Rhode Island to make our state more competitive. With that said, the current proposal must be reviewed and altered so as not to disturb ecosystems, impinge on property rights, and threaten the natural beauty of the area. I’m confident that, together, we can work with the FRA to develop a solution that avoids these damaging impacts, while still enhancing public transit.

Many Rhode Island households are struggling to make ends meet, which is why the Earned Income Tax Credit is so important to working families. I was glad to join community partners and my colleagues in government today to raise awareness of the #EITC and the difference it can make. If you’re not sure if you qualify, check out the IRS website for eligibility requirements and more information on free tax preparation services and other tax resources. #EITCAwarenessDay
There has never been and never should be a religious litmus test to enter the United States.

Back-to-back rallies on back-to-back weekends, fighting for the America that I love – an America that is inclusive and accepting and, most importantly, a place of freedom and equality. It is amazing to see Rhode Islanders mobilized and ready to fight for our democracy, and these demonstrations were replicated around the country and around the world. Tonight, I will join my colleagues in front of the Supreme Court to oppose policies that exclude and isolate instead of unite and empower.

To show support for marginalized communities and to celebrate diversity and inclusion, I am leading an effort to have Members of Congress bring with them, as a guest to the President’s address on February 28, someone who has, despite discrimination, made a positive impact on his or her community, exemplifying the ideals of our great nation.

I’m so glad that the House passed my United States-Israel Cybersecurity Cooperation Enhancement Act, and I call on my colleagues in the Senate to take the bill up without delay. The United States and Israel have a mutual interest in strengthening our cyber defenses, and this legislation will enable us to work together to develop innovative solutions to the threats we face in cyberspace.

“…in diversity there is beauty and there is strength. We all should know that diversity makes for a rich tapestry, and we must understand that all the threads of that tapestry are equal in value no matter their color.” – Maya Angelou  It is a challenging time in our country, especially for people of color. Black History Month is an important time for us to honor the civil rights champions who paved the way toward greater equality, and also recognize the tremendous need for today’s leaders and advocates, because there is much work left to be done. #BlackHistoryMonth
What an unbelievable game and comeback. Congratulations, New England Patriots! #SuperBowl51

I had a great time at New England Institute of Technology this weekend for the FIRST Tech Challenge Championship. I’m working in Washington to support STEM education and increase hands-on, technical education. Seeing this competition in action reminds me just how important this is. The enthusiasm of the students and the impressive projects they create demonstrate the great things that can be accomplished with the tools of STEM and the guidance of industry leaders. Congratulations to all of the RI FTC participants – you are Rhode Island’s next generation of innovators!

The confirmation hearing of newly confirmed Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos painted an alarming picture. She is, quite simply, unqualified for the job, with no real education experience and very little understanding of the complex and critical issues facing the department she hopes to lead. While I did not have a role in the confirmation process, I am deeply disappointed that, in an unprecedented move, the Vice President had to step in to break a tie and confirm this nominee. I have received many phone calls, emails and social media feedback from constituents – many of whom work in education – who are overwhelmingly opposed to Secretary DeVos. I share their concerns, and I applaud Senator Jack Reed and Senator Sheldon Whitehouse for their strong opposition to this appointment.

This National School Counselor Week, I’m so grateful for the hardworking counselors in Rhode Island and beyond who are on the front lines, helping students to successfully navigate career and educational pathways.
Everyone please stay safe and warm today! Stay off the roads, if possible, and follow Rhode Island Emergency Management Agency on their website and on social media for storm updates.

Today's appeals court ruling supports what I know to be true: that President Trump's executive action is unconstitutional and un-American. We have strong vetting processes in place for immigrants coming to America. The most intense checks are given to refugees - many of whom are women and children fleeing unspeakable violence. The President's claims that visitors from these Muslim majority nations are pouring into our country with malicious intent are factually inaccurate and serve only to fan the flames of intolerance. We cannot let fear alter the principles of religious freedom and equality that this nation was built upon, and I applaud the appeals court for this swift and just decision.
Join me and Senator Jack Reed, Senator Sheldon Whitehouse, and Congressman David Cicilline for a town hall meeting this Sunday at East Providence High School!
Tomorrow's Free File Briefing has been postponed. I will share the new date and time as soon as we are able to reschedule.

Incredible turnout. Thank you all for being with us and thank you for your advocacy! For those of you at home, follow the #RITownHall on Senator Jack Reed's Facebook page.   https://m.facebook.com/SenJackReed/

Thank you, again, to the hundreds of Rhode Islanders who braved the snow to attend yesterday’s RI Town Hall with the delegation. The turnout for the Women’s March in Rhode Island, in D.C., and beyond, was unprecedented. And yet, the very next weekend, another fantastic crowd turned out in opposition to the executive orders on immigration. The crowd yesterday reinforces the message loud and clear: your voices cannot and will not be ignored. We welcome the feedback. So whether it’s an in-person town hall, on social media, by email, or by phone, we want to keep hearing from you. I’ve been hosting quarterly Lunch with Langevin meetings for the past three years, and you can consider that a standing invitation to come see me, ask questions, and share your concerns.

Diversity makes our nation stronger, and I believe it should be celebrated. I am proud to call Dr. Ehsun Mirza Malang a friend, and I hope that his presence on February 28th will serve as a reminder to the President that true Americans come in every color and creed – and not all are born here.

I introduced a resolution yesterday to create a bipartisan, bicameral Joint Committee to investigate the Russian election hacks and Russian contact with the Trump campaign and Administration. Three Senate Committees and one House Committee currently have active investigations into this issue, but rather than launch multiple time-consuming and costly investigations, none of which would encompass the complete scope of Russian activity, we should direct our efforts and resources into a single Joint Committee with the power to cut across jurisdictional lines and get to the truth.
NA

Glad to see Thrillist is telling the rest of the world what we already know – Providence is “an artsy college town with student-friendly prices.”    https://www.thrillist.com/travel/nation/cheapest-cities-to-live-in-under-the-radar?ref=facebook-869

I am always proud to be back at my alma mater, Rhode Island College!  I am especially excited to work with new president, Frank Sanchez!  http://turnto10.com/news/education/new-president-takes-over-at-rhode-island-college

On Saturday morning, I will be joining U.S. Senators Jack Reed and Sheldon Whitehouse at Rhode Island College to rally against the dismantling of America’s health care system.  We must send a message to President Trump and Congressional Republicans that repealing the Affordable Care Act would jeopardize the health and financial security of millions of Americans. Under the Affordable Care Act, Rhode Island’s uninsured rate dropped from 12 percent to a record low of 4.5 percent.  A recent Urban Institute study estimates that 96,000 Rhode Islanders would lose their health insurance in 2019 if the Affordable Care Act is repealed.  Republicans in Congress have taken an initial step to repeal the Affordable Care Act, and have not introduced a plan to replace the program.

“It’s my hope that gallery is going to look like America,” said Rep. Jim Langevin (D-R.I.), who is leading an effort to have his colleagues bring diverse guests Tuesday and will be joined by Rhode Island Dr. Ehsun Mirza, a Muslim-American born in Pakistan. “It’s another reminder to the president that he’s not the arbiter of patriotism.”

"I want the President when he is looking up at the gallery when he is addressing the country and addressing congress to see the diversity of America. And, to be reminded in a respectful way that he really needs to work harder to try and be a uniter,” said Langevin.

Tonight’s speech was not as unifying as I had hoped – it was disappointingly long on rhetoric and short on details.   https://langevin.house.gov/press-release/langevin-statement-trump%E2%80%99s-address-congress

Today, I testified in front of the House Appropriations Committee to highlight my strong support for three priorities that would not only positively impact Rhode Island, but help to improve the lives of people across the nation:   (1) Funding the Lifespan Respite Care Act to safeguard the health of family caregivers while protecting the continuum of quality care for people with disabilities or chronic illnesses   (2) Investing in the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act to prepare students for the demands of the 21st century economy  (3) Supporting the Adoption Opportunities program to help find permanent families for youth in foster care.

Youth in foster care are particularly vulnerable to identity theft because so many adults in their lives have access to their private information. That's why, today, I reintroduced the Protect Children from Theft Act, which would help ensure that foster youth have the opportunity to enter adulthood with a clean credit history.  (https://langevin.house.gov/press-release/langevin-leads-reintroduction-bill-protect-foster-youth-identity-theft)

Our local food economy has become a major part of tourism and overall growth in our state.  Rhode Island grown Sons of Liberty, led by my good friend, and member of my Food First Advisory Committee, Mike Repucci, is a leader in the industry.  Once again, Sons of Liberty has earned a top national recognition.  Congratulations and well earned!

It was so inspiring for me to have my Arts and Culture Advisory Committee meeting at Hera Gallery in Wakefield.  And an extra thank you to Raymond "Two Hawks" Watson for teaching all of us about cultural tourism in Rhode Island.  #ArtsandCultureAdviosry

"I have long said that the ACA isn't perfect, and I am willing to work in a bipartisan manner to improve the law," Langevin said. "If enacted, the Republican plan will only lead to higher costs, less coverage, and increased strain on our health care system, our patients and our families."

Reps. Gerry Connolly (Va.) and Jim Langevin (R.I.) introduced the Fair, Accurate, Secure, and Timely (FAST) Voting Act to improve voter participation and voting system security and encourage automatic voter registration.  The bill would let states compete for federal funding to implement policy changes aimed at increasing voter access to elections and boosting voting system security. It is modeled after the Department of Education’s Race to the Top program, which provides funding for states to develop student assessments. The Election Assistance Commission would award grants to states based on their previous reform efforts and plans for future innovation.  “The right to vote is essential, and we must foster innovative solutions to bring down every barrier to casting a ballot. This is especially true for those in need of flexibility or assistance, such as people with disabilities, members of the armed services, seniors, and minority voters,” Langevin said Tuesday.

While the Republican Affordable Care Act repeal bill passed the House Budget Committee 19-17 today, I joined my colleagues at a hearing sponsored by Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer on the potentially devastating impacts of ACA repeal. It’s a forum Republicans refuse to have but allowed me to get a better understanding of just how damaging this proposal can be. See me speak at 2:25:55 #resistrepeal

The cuts proposed by President Trump today would sink the budget to a historic low, creating rampant insecurity in the lives of Americans. I believe we can defend our country from strategic threats while still working to deter economic insecurity here at home. #budget

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is crucial in helping to protect our environment and our economy.  It defends our coasts from storm surges, and provides up-to-the second data to farmers, forecasters, and fishermen. Unfortunately, President Trump’s budget proposal slashes #NOAA funding. Listen to my one minute speech on the House Floor from Wednesday night.

Please join Senator Sheldon Whitehouse, Senator Jack Reed and myself at a #townhall meeting at Coventry High School on Sunday from 1 to 3 p.m. It’s a great way to talk directly to us and share ideas about a wide range of issues.
It is not the least bit surprising that FBI Director Comey today verified what we knew already to be true: that President Trump’s wiretapping claims surrounding Trump Tower are utterly without merit.

Watch me and my fellow Democrats with Vice President Joe Biden to mark seven years since President Obama signed the Affordable Care Act into law, leading to improved health and economic security for hard-working Americans.

According to the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office, 24 million fewer Americans will have health insurance by 2026 under the Republican plan— a larger decline in health coverage than a straight repeal of the #AffordableCareAct. We should be working in a bipartisan way to improve the #ACA, not gutting it! http://buff.ly/2o5GW3Y
Watch me and my fellow Democrats fight to protect the health care coverage of American families in final House debate on #TrumpCare.

There hasn't been a single hearing on the Republican's health care plan to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, a law that has helped millions of Americans receive quality coverage. Instead of rushing a destructive through the House, we should be working together in a bipartisan manner to improve what is already in place.

Republicans refused to take a vote because they don’t have the numbers to pass this morally reprehensible legislation that will increase costs on hardworking families, reduce access to lifesaving care, and eliminate services for the sick, the poor, the elderly and people with disabilities #ACA #ProtectOurCare
We are at Coventry High School until 3p.m for a town hall meeting. If you can, join us or watch it live below.

President Trump’s executive order to start dismantling the #CleanPowerPlan puts Americans’ health at risk and only worsens the effects of climate change. The plan is an important blueprint to reduce the amount of emissions pouring into our atmosphere that pose significant long-term negative public health effects and will cause irreversible environmental damage.

Consumers should have a right to decide what happens to their browsing history, not have it sold by broadband providers. That's why I voted against yesterday's Republican measure that will repeal FCC rules to help protect consumer privacy. Watch my remarks on the House Floor.

I am deeply concerned with House Intelligence Committee Chairman Nunes’s recent conduct regarding both his visit to the White House grounds to meet with an unnamed source and his lack of transparency about the visit. I continue to support a bipartisan select committee to look into Russian meddling in the U.S. election.

The chemical attack in Syria was morally reprehensible, killing 70-plus innocent children and civilians. Let’s be clear: this attack is the fault of President Assad. He must be held accountable for his actions, as must the Russian regime that continues to enable his acts of carnage.

I am deeply troubled by the confirmation of #NeilGorsuch, particularly in light of the decision by Republican leaders to upend Senate tradition and, in a purely partisan fashion, eliminate the filibuster for Supreme Court nominees.

Federal funding for the arts and humanities has been immensely beneficial for American culture. Here is my special order from last week urging the President not to dismantle and defund the National Endowments for the Arts and Humanities.

Please spread the word! Artwork for my annual High School Art Competition is due April 28th. The lucky winner will get a scholarship offer and the honor of having their work hang in the U.S. Capitol for one year beginning in June.

ICYMI: I was honored to deliver a Purple Heart to the widow of veteran, Robert Liebrich, for his service during World War II. Here is my blog post on the family’s visit to my office to accept the award!

The deadline to submit an application for the HUD Lead and Healthy Homes Tech Studies grant is May 16. These grants provide support to study the links between household hazards and health conditions. For more information visit https://portal.hud.gov/hudportal/HUD?src=/program_offices/administration/grants/fundsavail/2017lhhtsnofa

I’m so glad to see House of Hope CDC restore the historic "Fair House" in Warwick and transform it into 10 affordable housing units. It’s a new chapter for this Pawtuxet Village landmark, and it continues the Fair House's legacy as a refuge for some of Rhode Island’s most vulnerable individuals.
This is a thoughtful way to honor one of Rhode Island’s fallen heroes, 1st Sergeant P. Andrew McKenna.
Today is #EarthDay2017! We must all do our part to protect our environment. To celebrate, volunteer for local clean-ups. Here’s a link to find one near you --->

Shellfish are a big part of Rhode Island’s vibrant seafood economy. Today, I attended the launch of the R.I. Shellfish Initiative at the University of Rhode Island that will support continued job growth and sustainable management of our shellfish resources. Here is a link to the R.I. Shellfish Management Plan ---> http://www.rismp.org/category/smp-updates/

I was recently interviewed by the Association for Career and Technical Education regarding my priorities to strengthen Career and Technical Education. I believe through continued investment in CTE programs, we can keep shrinking the skills gap in Rhode Island and the rest of the country. Please check it out.

There are new blog posts up about my visit to Bain+2, an afterschool program that helps at-risk students, the groundbreaking of Warwick’s Hyatt Place Hotel and Reading Across R.I. and why we need to continue to support the humanities. Check them out!

Here is my Floor speech about the importance of supporting programs that serve people with autism. We must invest in researching new interventions, provide support to families and caregivers, and fund programs that assist those living with autism well into adulthood #AutismAwarenessMonth

Today is the deadline for my annual High School Art Competition for students in the 2nd Congressional District. Students can submit one piece of art with the chance of winning a trip to Washington, D.C., a scholarship offer and the honor of having their work hang in the U.S. Capitol for one year beginning in June!

Celebrate #SmallBusinessWeek by shopping local and supporting Rhode Island’s many great small businesses. If you’re a small business, here is a link to some useful resources ---> https://www.sba.gov/offices/district/ri/providence
I introduced the PLUS Loan Disability Forgiveness Act yesterday that would provide student loan relief to parents of disabled children. Here is my Floor speech from last night

ICYMI: Here’s yesterday’s Tuesday’s with Liz interview about my work on the Lifespan Respite Care Act, my role as co-chair of the Bipartisan Disabilities Caucus, and my other legislative priorities on disability issues this Congress. Thanks for having me! Association of University Centers on Disabilities

The cuts to Medicaid proposed in the President’s health care bill will significantly impact schools that rely on this funding to provide services like preventative care and physical therapy to students with disabilities. This is one of the many reasons I’m voting no today on the American Health Care Act.

It is unconscionable that House Republicans have forced through a bill in the service of a purely partisan political goal at the expense of their constituents’ health. Rather than collaborate in a bipartisan manner to improve upon the ACA, Republicans have opted to support an initiative that will exacerbate issues of affordability and access for Rhode Islanders and all Americans.

Big congratulations to Rhode Island College and Moses Brown for being named 2017 U.S. Department of Education Green Ribbon Schools. They are among only 45 schools in the nation honored for this prestigious award. https://www2.ed.gov/programs/green-ribbon-schools/highlights-2017.pdf

In April, I visited the Cranston PriceRite and learned about their business model and how they provide quality, low-priced food to their customers. There’s a new post on my blog about the visit. http://langevin.house.gov/2nd-district/langevin-hits-rhode/spring-2017#April13

Two Rhode Island teens were honored in the 2017 Prudential Spirit of Community Awards for their outstanding volunteer service and dedication to supporting their community. Congratulations to Max Hempe of Wakefield and Haylee Balme of Coventry! https://spirit.prudential.com/
President Trump claims that Congress and the public have lost faith in the FBI when what they are losing faith in is his presidency.

Big congratulations to member of my Food First Advisory Committee and Matunuck Oyster Bar owner, Perry Raso, for winning four Providence Journal Reader’s Choice Awards! It is well deserved. http://buff.ly/2q36BxU
The Johnston Citizens Bank campus is making a lot of progress and is set to open in summer 2018. I recently toured the campus and have a new blog posted about my visit.  http://buff.ly/2pCQe8B
I introduced the Offshore WIND Act yesterday with Senators Sheldon Whitehouse, Jack Reed, and Ed Markey to encourage more clean and efficient wind projects like Block Island.

ICYMI: Last week, I announced the winners of the Congressional Art Competition! There were 60 submissions this year from talented high school students in the 2nd Congressional District.  1st Place: Arianna Deal, Grade 10, Cranston West High School, “Dreaming of Spring;” 2nd Place: Sarah Bannon, Grade 11, Nancy Stephens Gallery & School of Art and Scituate High School, “Ellis Island-Haven of Tears;” 3rd Place: Brittany Shippee, Grade 12, Scituate High School, “It’s A Yarn Thing.” Honorable Mentions:  Laura Murphy, Grade 11, Nancy Stephens Gallery & School of Art and  East Greenwich High School, “Kindergarten Superhero;” Mary Cofield, Grade 12, North Kingstown Senior High School, “Empty Frame;” Cherry Wang, Grade 12, Providence Country Day, “Self-Portrait;” I’ana Johnson, Grade 12, Coventry High School; “Hot Mama.”

Our intelligence community relies on trust in order to protect the homeland and our interests abroad, and to carelessly disclose such information betrays our allies, our service members, and our intelligence officials.

It’s Infrastructure Week, and today I will introduce the SAFE Bridges Act, a bill that will invest in our aging infrastructure by providing up to $170 million to repair Rhode Island’s crumbling, structurally deficient bridges.
If true, President Trump's actions revealed by The New York Times have stained the esteemed office he holds. Here is my full statement on the #ComeyMemos --->

According to the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office, the Senate #TrumpCare bill will eliminate coverage for 15 million people next year alone, and for 22 million by 2026. It will shrink Medicaid for the sick, elderly, and disabled, requiring states to cut services of enrollees. It will undermine federal protections for Essential Health Benefits and annual and lifetime limits. Americans deserve better!

Pleased to see my climate amendment pass in the House Armed Services Committee today! This amendment is a responsible first step in recognizing what most of the world already knows— that climate change is real, and it will have a devastating effect on the readiness of our armed forces.

The President’s plan is not tax reform. It’s a tax cut for the wealthy paid for by adding trillions of dollars to the deficit. We need a sensible tax reform package that reduces rates while closing loopholes to help ease the burden on individuals and businesses.

The Clean Power Plan will help our kids grow up in a cleaner and healthier world. It will reduce the toxins in our air, and it will focus our economy on jobs in the booming clean energy sector. President Trump’s reckless decision to kill this plan is inexcusable. Rhode Island has been a trailblazer in renewable energy development, and we should strive to enact policies that will create a sustainable future.

As part of National Cyber Security Awareness Month, I'm hosting a week-long Rhode Island #LangevinCybersecurity Tour. My first stop was a discussion with the Rhode Island Society of CPAs about how the NIST Cybersecurity Framework can help organizations be #CyberAware

I continued my #LangevinCybersecurity Tour yesterday by meeting with the Rhode Island State Police Computer Crimes Unit. If you are the victim of a cyber crime, whether it's identity fraud or ransomware, you can contact the State Police or any of these agencies for assistance. Knowing whom to go to for help is an important part of being #CyberAware

Day three of my #LangevinCybersecurity Tour was about personal security and the importance of being #CyberAware. I spoke to students in the #PTECH program at CCRI before joining local cybersecurity leader Sen. Lou DiPalma for his first annual Cyber Hygiene Event. Here are some steps you can take to stay safe online.

Yesterday was innovation day on the #LangevinCybersecurity Tour. I joined a panel at #AOSTech17 to talk about the evolution of cybersecurity risk management (more exciting than you'd think!) and then held my first Cybersecurity Advisory Committee meeting. If you have innovative ideas to help protect us online, share them through vulnerability disclosure mechanisms and information sharing platforms. Here are some ways how:
On Day 5 of the #LangevinCybersecurity Tour, I stopped by RI's largest employer of cyber professionals, SecureWorks.  Cybersecurity is a growing industry, and we need more people to meet the demand!

I wrapped up my #LangevinCybersecurity Tour yesterday at RI's first Hack Con. Cybersecurity challenges aren't going away, and we need more digital natives to protect us online. Good thing there are programs like CyberPatriot to build the next generation of cyber leaders!

The FCC’s proposal to end net neutrality is outrageous. We must maintain a free and open Internet, and prevent large companies from controlling what we see online. Watch my House Floor remarks: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OWhqKMiGu9A&feature=youtu.be
New blog is up about my #LangevinCybersecurity Tour! I had the privilege of speaking at Senator Lou DiPalma's first annual Cyber Hygiene Event at CCRI’s Newport Campus to promote safe habits online.
President Trump’s unprecedented decision to eliminate protections for our treasured public lands is an attack on our heritage and countless years of conservation efforts.

Attorneys General from Rhode Island to Oregon oppose the Concealed Carry Reciprocity bill because it would override local public safety decisions, endangering our communities and law enforcement officers. https://oag.ca.gov/system/files/attachments/press_releases/2017.10.22%20AGs%20Opposed%20to%20Conceal%20Carry%20Reciprocity%20w%20Sigs.pdf

The Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act will jeopardize the safety of Rhode Islanders and undermine our laws. Watch my House Floor remarks on this dangerous bill: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WsFSnC33oys&feature=youtu.be
On Pearl Harbor Remembrance Day, we honor the lives lost during the attack on Pearl Harbor and reflect on the ultimate sacrifice our brave service members made for our country.

Republicans just kicked the can down the road with a two week government funding bill without fixing critical programs like children’s health insurance.  We need bipartisan solutions, not more partisan dysfunction.

Tomorrow is my next Lunch with Langevin event at Harmony Lodge Family Restaurant from 12:30 to 2:30pm. Join me in an informal, one-on-one setting to discuss your thoughts and concerns. I hope to see you there!

Glad to see the President sign the National Defense Authorization Act that includes my language to address climate change.  But on the two-year anniversary of the Paris Agreement, we must do more by recommitting to address the climate crisis!

The FCC will vote tomorrow on a proposal to end Net Neutrality that will seriously impede the ability of consumers to access online content. Net Neutrality is essential to maintaining a free and open internet, and I urge the FCC to reject this misguided effort.

By repealing Net Neutrality, FCC Chairman Ajit Pai has sided with cable companies & other Internet service providers, putting profits above the public interest. I urge my colleagues to unite to block today’s effort and restore net neutrality.

Today, I proudly joined Senators Reed and Whitehouse, Congressman Cicilline, and child advocates at the Meeting Street School to call on Republicans to immediately reauthorize the Children’s Health Insurance Program. Republican inaction could end up costing 9 million children across the country – and 36,000 in Rhode Island – access to vital health care services. We must reauthorize CHIP!

New on Langevin Hits the Rhode: I wrapped up my #LangevinCybersecurity Tour at RI CyberPatriot’s first Hack Con. It’s wonderful to see students enthusiastic about cybersecurity!  https://medium.com/@JimLangevin/cyber-patriots-11590e1be54d

Although the President’s decision to remove climate change as a threat to our national security strategy is incredibly myopic, he cannot blind our military and intelligence officials to scientific fact.
We need to enact equitable and fiscally responsible tax reform, which the Republican tax bill fails to accomplish on all accounts.
I’m proud to lead a letter with my colleagues expressing our deep concern about potential censorship at CDC.

Rhode Islanders: there are just 10 days left to sign up for health insurance for 2018 through HealthSource RI. Make sure you get covered! Visit HealthSourceRI.com to compare plans that work best for you.

Republicans focused all their attention on passing a partisan tax giveaway to the wealthy and now are kicking the can down the road with another short-term government funding bill that leaves vital work undone.

The possibilities are endless when career and technical education students put their skills to use. What a touching story highlighting Scituate High School’s CTE Engineering program and their life-changing gift to a 9-year-old boy.
To all of our brave servicemembers, I wish you a very merry Christmas and happy New Year. Thank you for your dedication and service.
To everyone celebrating today, I wish you a very merry Christmas!

The Ocean State deserves to have fair representation on the Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council, which makes important decisions that affect the livelihood of Rhode Island fishermen. I’m proud to join Senator Jack Reed Senator Sheldon Whitehouse and Congressman David Cicilline in co-leading the Rhode Island Fishermen’s Fairness Act.
New on Langevin Hits the Rhode: I enjoyed a visit to Rhode Island Community Food Bank's Community Kitchen job training program where I met with their newest group of students.
There is still time to get covered! There are three days left to get 2018 health insurance coverage through HealthSource RI, and local walk-in centers have extended their hours.
With a record-setting cold snap hitting RI, it’s uplifting to see organizations like Crossroads Rhode Island helping the homeless stay warm.

The concerns of my constituents are always on my mind, and your feedback informs my work in Washington. Help me best represent your interests by joining me for a Town Hall meeting in August. I will give a brief update on some of the initiatives and policies I have been working on, and then I will take questions from the audience. From healthcare to economic development, I want to hear your thoughts and concerns. Come with questions, and bring a friend or neighbor!   I will host a Town Hall on Tuesday, August 8th at 6 p.m., at Narragansett Town Hall, located at 25 5th Avenue, in Narragansett.   This meeting is open to the ublic. I look forward to having a productive conversation about the issues facing our state and our country, from growing jobs and strengthening the economy to protecting Medicare and advocating for our students.

EVENT UPDATE: The Free File Briefing has been postponed due to a forecast of inclement weather on Monday morning. Please check back for updates, as we will schedule a new date soon.   .................................................................  Join Congressman Jim Langevin, U.S. Senators Jack Reed & Sheldon Whitehouse, Mayor Scott Avedisian and Lt. Governor Daniel McKee for the annual Free File Briefing to highlight the IRS and Rhode Island Free File programs.    Free File provides FREE online federal and state income tax preparation and e-filing services to lower and moderate income taxpayers.   Please share this invitation with other community leaders and activists. Help us spread the word!  To RSVP, email Lori Baux at MLBaux@aol.com or call 202-265-8148. For more information about Free File, visit www.irs.gov/freefile, www.tax.ri.gov, or www.taxprephelp.org.

For the 17th consecutive year, I am hosting the Rhode Island Second Congressional District High School Art Competition. Submitted entries from high school-aged students living in the Second Congressional District will be showcased at the art competition ceremony at the Warwick Mall on Sunday, May 7th, from 1 p.m. to 3 p.m.  One lucky student will win the grand prize— a trip to Washington, D.C, a scholarship offer and the honor of having their work hang in the U.S. Capitol for one year beginning in June.

In commemoration of the 5th anniversary of Superstorm Sandy, Congressman Jim Langevin will be joined by federal, state, and local officials, as well as environmental leaders, for a press conference highlighting efforts to address the impacts of climate change.  The recent wave of hurricanes that have battered the Southeast and the Caribbean have underscored the need to promote climate resiliency.  In addition to supporting these initiatives in Rhode Island, Langevin is currently leading an effort to assess the national security implications of global warming.

Come join Congressman Langevin at The National Hotel on Block Island for his 12th Lunch with Langevin event! Share your thoughts and concerns about his work in Washington and in Rhode Island and enjoy some free refreshments.  Congressman Jim Langevin (D-RI) launched his Lunch with Langevin program in 2014 in the hopes of engaging Rhode Islanders and getting feedback on the issues that are important to them. Each quarter, Langevin holds open office hours at a restaurant in the Second District, and constituents are invited to come and share their questions or concerns in an informal, one-on-one setting.

U.S. Senators Jack Reed and Sheldon Whitehouse and U.S. Representatives Jim Langevin and David Cicilline rally with Rhode Islanders to fight back against the GOP plan to dismantle America's health care system.

The concerns of my constituents are always on my mind, and your feedback informs my work in Washington. Help me best represent your interests by joining me for a Town Hall meeting in August. I will give a brief update on some of the initiatives and policies I have been working on, and then I will take questions from the audience. From healthcare to economic development, I want to hear your thoughts and concerns. Come with questions, and bring a friend or neighbor!   I will host a Town Hall on Tuesday, August 22nd at 6 p.m., in Council City Chambers at Warwick City Hall, located at 3275 Post Road, in Warwick.   This meeting is open to the public. I look forward to having a productive conversation about the issues facing our state and our country, from growing jobs and strengthening the economy to protecting Medicare and advocating for our students.
